entry.title: Time off Finland - accrual rules and best practices package
entry.content:
Dear community, 

I'm coming to ask if there are customers actually being able to work with Time off in Finland, and having the accrual rules working correctly in the cases of parental leaves.. I've been checking the best practices solution deployed in 1H 2024 but this solution does not seem to fulfill the legal requirements. 1H 2024 Release Highlights of SAP Best Practices f... - SAP Community

@NeeleshKamath 

I've been working with a Finnish customer which claims the following legal requirement: Per child, the employee accumulates holidays for a maximum of 160 days of parental leave. This count is made Monday to Saturday. The moment the employee reaches that limit, he stops accumulating holidays in the months he is still absent due to the same child birth. The employee can take the parental leave until the child becomes 2 years old. 

This needs to work together with the Finnish 14 days rule : an employee accumulates holidays for a certain month as long as he has worked at least 14 days in a month. That can be controlled with rule functions "Get Number Of Working Days Or Hours For Period()" from accruable start date to accruable end date. (OK until there)

So what the Best Practices rule (SFCC_ACC_FIN_Holiday_Credit_Accruals)  does is the following: count parental leaves in deduction quantity up to 160 days (monday to saturdays), and from that moment, penalize the employee. In a month, we will get the working days MINUS the days above 160 to see if it is above/below 14 days for the accrual. This solution is never considering which child the absence is about (what if you have multiple children?) and never considering the 2 years period mentioned above (it is checking the 160 limit in the year). 

As a result: this would never work well in reality!

For example imagine an employee has parental leave (reaching 160 days) on the 28th of June 2025, and he is on parental leave until the 12th of july (Saturday).

According to the Best Practices rule, the working days in july are 23. 

The days exceeding 160 days are from the 1st of july until the 12th (in yellow), saturdays included = 11

23 minus 11 = 12 days. 12 days is below 14 days, so the employee should not be eligible to accumulate holidays in that month. 

But in reality the employee should accumulate holidays because: 

Working days = 23

Working Days absent due to parental leave = 9

23 minus 9 = 14 days. Equal or above to the 14 days limit. so he would accrue days for that month. 

The difference is mixing units: working days vs deduction quantity. And deduction quantity days could be even greater than the working days!

So, seriously, has any company been able to work with this successfully?

 

Thank you very much for your time

Laura

entry.title: Re: Handling inventory updates from EWM to S/4HANA Cloud...
entry.content:
Hi Lakshmipathi,

Dear SAP Support,

I would like to reopen this ticket with additional information regarding the handling of inventory differences (physical inventory postings) in the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ↔ decentralized EWM integration (scope item 7L1).

Current Situation

  • We are running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integrated with a decentralized EWM system.

  • Standard logistics flows work correctly: inbound deliveries, outbound deliveries, pick denial/short-pick quantities are properly reflected back into S/4 via goods issue confirmation.

  • However, physical inventory (PI) differences posted in EWM are not replicated to S/4, which causes stock discrepancies between the two systems.

SAP’s Previous Suggestion
We received the advice that PI differences could be forwarded via Boomi/CPI using an API.

Why this does not work in our scenario

  • In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the only relevant API for posting stock adjustments is API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV.

  • Direct posting of goods movements (e.g. 701/702) via this API works for non-EWM storage locations.

  • But for EWM-managed storage locations, S/4 requires all postings to come through deliveries confirmed by EWM. Direct goods movement postings on those locations are not accepted.

  • This means that forwarding PI differences from EWM to S/4 via Boomi/CPI and calling API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV will not update stock in S/4, as the postings are rejected for EWM-managed storage locations.

Conclusion / Clarification Requested

  • The current 7L1 scope does not support replication of PI differences from decentralized EWM to S/4 Public Cloud.

  • The suggested workaround (Boomi/CPI calling an API) cannot function for EWM-managed storage locations.

Request
Could you please confirm:

  • Is there any supported or planned method in S/4 Public Cloud ↔ decentralized EWM integration to replicate PI differences to S/4?

  • If not, can SAP officially confirm that this is out of scope and must be solved with a custom extension, for example a customizing or enhancement in EWM that is triggered by a posting in the Difference Analyzer and automatically creates and sends an adjustment delivery to S/4?

Thank you for your clarification.

entry.title: SAP Completes Acquisition of SmartRecruiters
entry.content:
SAP has announced that it has completed the acquisition of SmartRecruiters, a leading provider of enterprise-grade talent acquisition software. As we shared last month, this acquisition marks a significant milestone in SAP’s commitment to delivering the capabilities our customers need today while laying the foundation for innovation in the future. 

The SmartRecruiters platform, known for its intuitive user experience and seamless workflows, will now be integrated with the SAP SuccessFactors Human Capital Management (HCM) suite. This addition to the SAP SuccessFactors portfolio will make it easier for enterprises to manage the entire hiring lifecycle, from sourcing to onboarding, with enhanced AI-enabled recruiting capabilities that result in faster time-to-hire, improved candidate experiences, and deeper analytics for workforce planning.  

SmartRecruiters customers will maintain the flexibility to continue using SmartRecruiters solutions with SAP or other HCM solutions. 

What’s Next? 

Now that the acquisition has closed, we will begin the process of product and company integration. 

We will share more information as it becomes available. For more information, please refer to the official announcement or reach out to your SAP representative. 

Join us virtually at SAP Connect to learn more about the future of SAP SuccessFactors and SmartRecruiters.

entry.title: Re: Old Supplier invoice not created with reference to in...
entry.content: The supplier invoice creation from the intercompany billing STO depends on the integration setup being active at the moment the billing document is created. Since the configuration was not yet in place, the supplier invoice was not triggered for CBST billing type. To solve this, I'd recommend you to once the configuration is active, cancel and recreate the CBST billing document. This will trigger the supplier invoice creation.

entry.title: Re: New Pipeline Concept features: new partner id definition, alternative partner, bypass option
entry.content:
@mdhira I was about to update the script but then figured out that you could run your P2P scenario on Edge Integration Cell already today, you just have to define a header partnerID in your scenario-specific inbound flow, this header is passed to the generic outbound flow, and when set your script won't fail. Usually this header holds the configuration scenario name and is used to call the Partner Directory, in your case you don't need it to call the Partner Directory but to ensure that the script won't fail, so you can choose any value.

Some background:

I intended to change this part assuming that when running the script on Edge Integration Cell, the service will be null, and if null I would then skip all the rest of the code. However, I just learned that although the Partner Directory is not supported yet on Edge, the Partner Directory tables already exist on Edge and hence this script will never throw an exception.

def service = ITApiFactory.getApi(PartnerDirectoryService.class, null);
if (service == null){
throw new IllegalStateException("Partner Directory Service not found");
}

So, the reason why the script fails is this part where we throw an error if partnerID is not set which is the case for P2P scenarios where you directly store the message in the last JMS queue PIPQ04 bypassing the main pipeline.

// get pid
def headers = message.getHeaders();
def Pid = headers.get("partnerID");
if (Pid == null){
throw new IllegalStateException("Partner ID not found in sent message");
}

So, to run P2P scenario without involving the main pipeline, you need to define the following headers in the scenario-specific inbound flow:

  • SAP_OutboundProcessingEndpoint with value ProcessDirect end point of your scenario-specific outbound flow
  • partnerID with any value
  • optionally: maxJMSRetries to reduce the number of attempts to restart failed messages

Long term we can make the script more robust so that it also works without the partnerID but for the time being you are not blocked. We also think about to support more use cases by maintaining more parameters in the scenario-specific inbound flows so that the Partner Directory doesn't need to be called and hence more scenarios can be run on Edge as long as the Partner Directory is not supported on Edge.

Alex

@xavierlegarrec - Thanks for mentioning the API. 

I tested this one for a specific plan using postman

/rest/rewards/compensation/v1/employeeCompensations?$expand=salary&$filter=compPlanId eq 35224&$top=25&$skip=0&templateId=501

entry.title: Developing Processes in SAP Build Process Automation for Integrated Product Development
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) is SAP’s new low-code/no-code platform that replaces Business Application Studio (BAS) for workflow development. With SBPA, workflows can be modeled, automated, and integrated visually, making it easier to connect business processes with collaboration scenarios.

In this article, we will walk through the complete journey: creating your first process in SBPA, deploying and running it in Integrated Product Development (IPD). You can follow the step-by-step instructions together with the screenshots to easily reproduce each step on your own system.

To get started, you need two prerequisites: a properly configured SBPA environment and an existing IPD Collaboration. Guidance for setting up Collaboration can be found in the official SAP Help for IPD Collaboration, while instructions for preparing SBPA are available in the SBPA Setup Guide.

 

Build you first Process

Step 1: Create a New Project

When you first log in to SAP Build Process Automation, you will see the Welcome to SAP Build page. Since there are no projects available yet, you need to start by creating a new one.

  1. Go to the All Projects section.
  2. Click on the Create button (highlighted in the top-right corner).

Step 2: Select the Project Type

In the Create Project wizard, you first need to define the objective of your project.

  1. Choose Automated Process (the middle option).
    • This option allows you to build process automations using drag-and-drop simplicity within SAP Build.
    • After selecting Automated Process, click Next to proceed.

Step 3: Choose the Development Type

After defining the objective, you now select the type of development configuration for your project.

  1. You will see two options:
    • Process – Build a business process to automate a workflow (e.g., sales order automation, invoice management, approval flows).
    • Automation – Automate repetitive tasks across applications (e.g., robotic process automation for manual tasks).
  2. For this tutorial, select Process.
    • This option enables you to design complete workflows with multiple steps, approvals, and integrations.
  3. Once selected, click Next to proceed to the project setup.

Step 4: Define the Project Name and Description

Next, you need to provide a meaningful name and description for your project. This will help you and your team easily identify the purpose of the process later.

  1. In the Name field, enter a clear and descriptive title for your project.
  2. In the Description field, provide additional details about the project’s purpose or scope.
  3. Once completed, click Review to proceed to the summary step.

Step 5: Review and Create the Project

The final step of the project creation wizard is to review your configuration before creating the project.

  1. The Summary page displays an overview of your selections:
    • Objective
    • Type
    • Name
    • Description
  2. Carefully check that all information is correct.
    • If needed, use the Edit links to make adjustments.
  3. Once everything looks good, click Create (bottom-right corner).

Your new project will now be generated, and you will be taken to the project workspace where you can start designing and automating your business process.

 

Step 6: Create a New Process

After creating the project, the next step is to define your first process inside it.

  1. In the Create Process dialog, provide the following details:
    • Name*: Enter a clear and descriptive process name.
    • Identifier*: Automatically filled
    • Description: Optionally, add a short description explaining the purpose of the process.
  2. Once all required fields are filled out, click Create.

Your process will be added to the project, and you can now begin designing the workflow by adding triggers, actions, and automation steps.

Step 7: Define a Process Trigger

Every process in SAP Build needs a trigger to define how it will start.

  1. Add a Trigger.
  2. In the Trigger configuration, you will see multiple options:
    • Submit a Form – The process starts when a user submits a predefined form.
    • API Trigger – The process is started by an external system or application through an API call.
    • Wait for an Event – The process begins when a specific event occurs.
    • Scheduled Trigger – The process runs automatically on a defined schedule.
  3. To use BPA with IPD, select API Trigger.
    • This option allows your process to be called programmatically by IPD.
  4. Select a name for your Trigger

 

Step 8: Configure Process Variables

To make your process dynamic, you need to define variables such as inputs, outputs, or custom fields. These variables allow data to flow through the process.

  1. Open the Process Details panel by clicking the side arrow button on the right hand side of the screen.
  2. Navigate to the Variables tab.
  3. Under Process Inputs, click Configure to define the data that your process should receive when triggered.
    • Process Inputs: Data passed into the process when it starts (e.g., order ID, customer name).
    • Process Outputs: Data that the process returns after execution.
    • Custom Variables: Additional internal variables you can use within the process flow.

 

Step 9: Define Process Inputs for BPA–IPD Connection

In order to establish the connection between BPA and IPD, you must configure the Process Inputs exactly as shown. These inputs are required for the API trigger to pass data correctly into the process.

  1. Open the Configure Process Inputs dialog.
  2. Add the following two inputs:

Important: If these inputs are not configured correctly, the API trigger will not be able to pass the required values, and the integration with IPD will fail.

  • Name: Subject
    • Identifier: subject
    • Description
    • Type: String
  • Name: Business Key
    • Identifier: businessKey
    • Description
    • Type: String
  • Make sure that both fields are created exactly with these Names and Identifiers.
    • The Identifier values (subject, businessKey) are case-sensitive and must match exactly to ensure proper data exchange with IPD.

Once everything is set, click Apply.

Step 10: Bind Process Inputs to the Process Details

After creating the required inputs (Subject and Business Key), you must bind them to the process definition so that they are recognized and used by BPA when triggered.

  1. Close and reopen the Process Details Panel.
  2. In the Process Content panel (on the left), expand Process Inputs.
    • You should see the variables Business Key and Subject listed.
  3. In the Process Details section (on the right):
    • Bind the Subject input variable, or
    • Enter a custom text string (e.g., IPD Process).
    • For the Subject field, you can either:
    • For the Business Key field, you must bind the Business Key input variable.

Important:

  • The Business Key is required. It uniquely identifies the process instance with a collaboration room.
  • The Subject is more flexible, it can either use the variable or a static text, depending on how you want the process name to appear in the work items tab of the collaboration room

 

Step 11: Add the First Step to the Process

Now that the trigger and process inputs are defined, you can begin building the workflow by adding steps between the trigger and the end node.

In the process flow, click the “+” symbol between the ProcessTrigger and the End node.

Step 12: Add a Form Step

When you add a step to your process, you can choose from different task types such as Approval, Automation, Email, or Decision.

  1. In the Choose what happens next dialog, select Form.
    • A Form step allows you to create a user-friendly form that can be filled out by process participants.
    • This is ideal for capturing data inputs (e.g., request details, feedback, approvals) at runtime.
  2. After selecting Form, you will be prompted to either:
    • Reuse an existing form already available in the project, or
    • Create a new blank form from scratch.

In this tutorial, we will continue by selecting Blank Form to design a new one.

Step 13: Configure the Form Step

Once the Form has been added to your process, you need to configure its general settings and assign key properties.

  1. In the Form step configuration panel (right side), define the following:
    1. Step Name: A descriptive name for the form step (e.g., MyTestForm).
  2. Set the required fields
    • Subject*:
    • Description: Optionally add a short explanation for the form’s purpose.
    • Priority*: Select the task priority (e.g., Low, Medium, High).
    • Users: Enter individual user mails, seperated by a comma.
    • Groups: Assign the task to a predefined user group.

Step 14: Open the Form Editor

After configuring the general settings for your form step, you can now design the form itself.

  1. In the Form Step Configuration panel, click Open Editor (next to the Form field).
    • This will open a new tab with the Form Designer where you can add and arrange input fields.

 

Step 15: Design the Form in the Form Editor

Once inside the Form Editor, you can create the layout and define the fields that the user will interact with during the process.

  1. Add and configure form elements:
    • Use the toolbar on the left (Text, Headings, Input fields, Checkboxes, Dropdowns, etc.) to drag components into the form area.
    • In this example, a Text Field labeled Test Data is added as a required field.
    • You can also include links, buttons, or additional sections for richer forms.
  2. Customize the form content:
    • Add a descriptive title or instructions (e.g., Please enter some test data).
    • Define placeholders, default values, and whether a field is mandatory.
  3. Save the form:
    • Once you’ve added and configured your fields, click Save in the top-right corner.

Saving ensures the form is available in your process and can be used in runtime execution.

Step 16: Save the Process

Once the process has been designed, you need to save and then release it to make it executable.

  1. Go back to the process
  2. Save the process
    • Click the Save button (top right corner).
    • This ensures all recent changes including triggers, forms, and variables are stored in the project.

The status will update to Saved.

Step 17: Define the Release Version and Notes

When you release the process, you need to provide versioning information and optionally describe the changes.

  1. In the Release Project dialog, enter the following details:
    • Use semantic versioning:
      • Major (X.0.0) for big new features or breaking changes.
      • Minor (0.X.0) for enhancements or smaller changes.
      • Patch (0.0.X) for bug fixes.
    • Release Version: Define the version number (e.g., 1.0.0).
    • Release Notes: Provide a short summary of the main changes in this version (e.g., Initial release with form input).

Click Release to finalize.

Step 18: Confirm and Deploy the Released Project Version

After releasing the project, SAP Build confirms that the process has been published successfully.

  1. A green confirmation message appears at the top of the screen:
    • Click Show project version to open details of the released version.
  2. In the Project Version Overview, you can review:
    • The artifacts (e.g., IPD Process, MyTestForm).
    • The triggers that start the process.
    • The dependencies, if any.
  3. To make the process executable in your environment, click Deploy (top-right corner).
    • Release makes a version available.

Deploy activates it so the process can actually be triggered (via UI or API).

Step 19: Confirm Deployment and Trigger Creation

When deploying a project version, SAP Build will inform you about the effect on triggers.

  1. In the Effect on Triggers dialog, you can see which triggers will be created or updated.
    • In this example: ProcessTrigger → Will be created.
  2. Click Deploy to confirm.
    • This activates the trigger and makes the process executable in your environment.

Once deployed, external systems (like IPD) can call this trigger via API to start the process.

Step 20: Verify the Deployment Status

After deployment, you can confirm that your process is active and ready to run.

  1. In the Project Overview, the status indicators will show:
    • Deployed → The process version has been successfully deployed.
    • Active → The process is currently live and can be triggered.

Step 21: Switch to IPD

Once your process is deployed and active in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA), you can continue with the integration in IPD (Integrated Product Development).

Step 22: Open Workflow Properties in IPD

To connect your deployed BPA process with IPD, you first need to configure the workflow properties.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, locate the tile Workflow Properties.

Click on Workflow Properties to open the configuration settings

Step 23: Create a Workflow Property for the BPA Process in IPD

Workflow Properties in IPD allow you to define additional technical parameters for integrating and controlling your process.

  1. In the Workflow Properties overview, click Create.
  2. In the Create Workflow Property dialog:
    • Workflow*: Select your BPA workflow (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Workflow Property*: Enter a property name.
    • Property Value: Define the value to be used for this property.
    • Property Value Description: (Optional) Add a description to make the property easier to understand.
  3. Additional options:
    • Assign Users to Business Role: Links the property to specific business roles.
    • Default Property Value: Provides a fallback if no value is passed at runtime.
    • Allow Changes at Runtime: Enable this if the property should be overwritten during execution.
  4. Click Save to create the workflow property.

Step 24: Open Configure Collaboration in IPD

To finalize the integration and ensure that your BPA process can be executed within IPD, you need to configure collaboration settings.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, locate the Configure Collaboration tile.
  2. Click on Configure Collaboration.

Step 25: Define a New Collaboration Type in IPD

To connect your BPA process with a collaboration, you must create a new collaboration type.

  1. In the New Collaboration Type dialog, provide the following details:
    • ID*: A unique identifier for this collaboration type (e.g., BACT).
    • Description*: A descriptive name (e.g., Build Process Automation Collaboration Type).
    • Purpose: (Optional) Enter the business purpose of this collaboration type.
    • Status: Initially set to In Preparation.
  2. Under General Information:
    • Status Profile*: Select a profile that defines the process status lifecycle (e.g., Simple Statusnet (SIMPLE)).
    • Processing Status Profile: (Optional) Add if additional status handling is required.
    • Workflows*: Select your deployed workflow from BPA (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Reference Objects: (Optional) Add objects if you want to link the collaboration type to specific business entities.
    • Collaboration Header Fields: (Optional) Add header fields to store additional metadata.
  3. Under Configure Tabs:
    • Select the tabs that should be available for this collaboration type (e.g., Work Items, Shared Documents, Shared Product Data).
    • To add a workflow you must add the Work Items Tab.
  4. Click Save to create the collaboration type.

Step 26: Activate the Collaboration Type (Set to “In Use”)

After creating your new Collaboration Type, you must activate it so it can be used within IPD.

  1. In the Collaboration Types overview, locate the entry you just created (e.g., BACT – Build Process Automation Collaboration Type).
  2. Select the checkbox next to the ID.
  3. Click Set to “In Use” in the toolbar.
    • This changes the status from In Preparation to In Use.
    • Once active, the Collaboration Type can be used in collaboration scenarios and will connect with your process.

Step 27: Create a Collaboration

Once your Collaboration Type is set to In Use, you can create a new Collaboration with the Collaboration Type.

  1. Navigate to the My Collaborations in the Collaboration launchpad.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Enter the required details:
    • Collaboration Type: Select the Collaboration Type you activated earlier (e.g., BACT).
    • Collaboration Name: Provide a meaningful name (e.g., Build Process Automation Testing).
  4. Save the Collaboration.

From the My Collaborations Overview click on the arrow on the right to access a Collaboration.

Step 28: Add Workflow to the Collaboration

To connect your Collaboration instance with the BPA process, you must add the workflow that was deployed earlier.

  1. Open your Collaboration (e.g., Build Process Automation Testing).
  2. Navigate to the Work Items tab.
  3. At the bottom of the screen, click Add Workflow.

Step 29: Configure the Workflow in the Collaboration

When you add a workflow to a collaboration, you must configure its details.

  1. In the Add Workflow dialog:
    • Workflow*: Select the deployed workflow (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Title*: This is automatically filled. You can adjust if needed, but once saved, it cannot be changed.
  2. (Optional) Linked Files and Folders:
    • You can attach documents that will be shared with participants in this collaboration.
  3. (Optional) Linked Reference Object:
    • If required, assign reference objects that provide additional business context (e.g., product IDs, project numbers).
  4. (Optional) Comments:
    • Add notes or context for this workflow assignment.
  5. Click Add to link the workflow to the collaboration.

Step 30: Monitor the Workflow Execution

After adding the workflow to your collaboration, you can now start and observe the process execution.

  1. Go to the Work Items tab of your Collaboration (you may have to refresh).
  2. You will see an entry for the workflow you just added (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Running → The workflow is active.
    • Ready → A form or task is waiting for user action.
    • Completed → The workflow or step is finished.
    • The Title column shows the subject defined earlier (e.g., This is my test form).
    • The Status column indicates the current execution state:

Step 31: Open “My Inbox” from the Collaboration Launchpad

To act on user tasks created by your BPA workflow (e.g., the Form step), use the My Inbox app.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, open My Inbox.

Step 32: Complete the Form Task in My Inbox

This is the user task created by your BPA workflow. Fill it in and submit to advance the process.

  1. Enter the required data:
    • In the field Test Data (marked with an asterisk), type a value. Required fields must be filled before submission.
    • Optional: follow any informational links shown in the form (e.g., Link to sap.com).
  2. Submit the task:
    • Click Submit to send the form back to the workflow.
    • If validation errors appear, correct them and submit again.

Step 33: Verify Workflow Completion in the Collaboration

Confirm that your end-to-end flow finished successfully.

  1. In the Collaboration view, open your Collaboration
  2. Open the Work Items tab.
  3. Check the rows for your workflow (e.g., IPD Process) and its task (e.g., This is my test form).
    • Status should be Completed.
    • Assignee/Processor, Created On, and Completed On show who finished it and when.

Conclusion

Good job! You created your first process in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) and successfully deployed it in Integrated Product Development (IPD). With this foundation in place, you now have a running workflow that you can trigger, monitor, and extend.

The next step is to take your automation even further by integrating APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This will allow you to enrich your workflows with collaboration features, business data, and advanced automation scenarios. Stay tuned for my next blog post, where I will guide you through adding APIs to your SBPA processes step by step.

Alexandra Rong,
Business Process Consultant for SAP IPD,
alexandra.rong@sap.com

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI Checkbox events are not getting received imme...
entry.content:
SAP Help Checkboxes and Radio Buttons with Function Codes

Checkboxes and radio buttons without a function code behave like normal input/output fields. Clicking the object changes the contents of the field, but does not trigger the PAI event. (Clicking a pushbutton, on the other hand, always triggers the PAI event, even if it has an empty function code.)

That is why you don't get an "event" when checking a checkbox.

 

When a function code is assigned to a checkbox or radio button, clicking it not only changes the field contents, but also triggers the PAI event and places the function code in the OK CODE field.

Once a function code is assigned to a checkbox, a PAI event is triggered when the checkbox is clicked.

entry.title: Re: Considerations on multiple Distribution Channels (and...
entry.content:
Yes how the “common DC” logic actually works is when you define a common distribution channel in VOR1, you’re telling the system “If master data (customer or material) is missing in DC X, look for it in the reference DC Y.” This applies to both customer and material master data — there’s no standard way to say “only for materials”.

So in your example:

If you maintain a material in US01/D0, you can use it in US01/D1 or US01/D2 without creating separate sales views. The system will pull from D0. If you maintain a customer in US01/D1, you can also use it in US01/D2 if D2 points to D1 in VOR1, but in your case you don’t want that.

Because you can’t make “common DC for materials only” in pure standard, you have two main options:

Option A – Use common DC, but control customer creation

  • Keep your D0 “technical” DC as the reference for all others in VOR1.
  • Maintain all materials in D0 only.
  • Maintain customers only in their real DCs (D1, D2, etc.).
  • Prevent accidental customer creation in D0 by:
    • Removing authorisation for DC D0 in V_KNA1_VKO.
    • Enforcing MDG/workflow rules that reject customer creation in D0.
  • This way, the common DC works for materials, but customers are still separate in practice.

Technically, the system still could use the common DC for customers if someone created them in D0,  so you need governance.


Option B – No common DC, automate material extension

  • Don’t use VOR1 at all.
  • Maintain material sales views in one DC (e.g. D0) and use MM17, LSMW, or Fiori mass maintenance to extend them to all other DCs automatically when a new material is created.
  • This keeps customer data completely separate by DC, and avoids the “Sales area not defined” issue.
  • Downside: you still have multiple sales views in the database, but the creation is automated so there’s no manual effort.

If you ask me which one to choose

If governance is strong and you can lock down customer creation in the technical DC → Option A is cleaner (only one set of material views).

If governance is weak or you want to avoid any risk of cross‑DC customer sharing → Option B is safer (but uses automation to avoid manual work).

entry.title: Re: Using class CL_ABAP_PARALLEL for mass parallel dialog work processes
entry.content:
For information, if CL_ABAP_PARALLEL is instantiated without P_TIMEOUT (default value 0), CL_ABAP_PARALLEL will calculate a timeout for RFC tasks which depends on the context where CL_ABAP_PARALLEL is instantiated:

  • If CL_ABAP_PARALLEL runs in dialog, the RFC tasks will use the high priority timeout i.e., the one defined by the profile parameter rdisp/scheduler/prio_high/max_runtime which is by default 660 seconds.
  • If CL_ABAP_PARALLEL runs in background, the RFC tasks will use the low priority timeout i.e., the one defined by the profile parameter rdisp/scheduler/prio_low/max_runtime which is by default unlimited (no timeout).

This is documented in this question, which concerns CL_ABAP_PARALLEL: Solved: TIMEOUT dump (11 min.) for RFC in low priority (ru... - SAP Community.

entry.title: SAP TechEd 2025: Elevate your learning, certification, and community experience
entry.content:
SAP TechEd (November 4–6, 2025) is just around the corner, bringing the SAP Community together for three days of learning and exchange. As a registered attendee, you’ll have the chance to access a 25% discount on SAP Certification with two exam attempts — a great opportunity to continue building your skills and showcase your expertise. 

Beyond certification, there are even more ways to get involved early. From community celebrations to hands-on learning and exclusive attendee benefits, SAP TechEd in 2025 offers multiple paths to build skills and connect with peers. 

Here are four highlights you won’t want to miss:  

Devtoberfest by SAP TechEd: September 29 – October 24, 2025 

Kicking things off is Devtoberfest, a multi-week, developer-focused celebration leading up to SAP TechEd. Running from September 29 to October 24, Devtoberfest is an opportunity to learn, connect, and celebrate coding with the global developer community.  

Expect tutorials, challenges, and technical sessions designed to help you sharpen your skills. Participation is flexible, and every activity you complete earns points as part of the experience. It’s an engaging way to connect with fellow developers while exploring the latest SAP technologies.  

Devtoberfest also includes a contest with a grand prize: winners from past years have joined retreats and exclusive SAP TechEd experiences, and last year’s winners will be with us in Berlin. The tradition continues in 2025, with the grand prize leading to a special retreat at a future SAP TechEd event in 2026.

Discover Devtoberfest by SAP TechEd.  

Explore the Learning Zone  

 

Why wait until November to start building new skills? The learning zone for SAP TechEd is open now, packed with resources to help you get a jumpstart on your learning journey. 

Dive in to take advantage of: 

  • Over 40+ interactive value journeys and solution showcases.  
  • More than 30+ free, self-paced learning journeys aligned to SAP TechEd content tracks.  
  • Dozens of demos and real-world use cases offering hands-on experience.  

Whether you’re looking to prepare for certification, deepen your knowledge, or explore new technologies, the learning zone provides a head start.  

Explore the learning zone today to get started on your SAP TechEd journey.  

Certification Benefits for Attendees  

SAP TechEd in 2025 also brings valuable opportunities to earn your SAP Certification.  

  • Exclusive 25% Discount: All registered attendees, whether joining virtually or onsite, will receive a 25% discount on SAP Certification. This discount applies to the two exam attempts booking and supports all participants on their path towards success. 
  • Free SAP Certification at SAP TechEd in Berlin: On the final event day, in-person attendees have the chance to take a free certification exam on site.

Learn more and register now. 

These benefits make it easier than ever to validate your skills and showcase your expertise. 

Get Ready for SAP TechEd in 2025  

By joining Devtoberfest, exploring the learning zone, and taking advantage of certification offers, you can make the most of your SAP TechEd experience before the event even begins. 

This year, SAP TechEd 2025 is back as a hybrid experience—join us in Berlin or connect online for learning and networking opportunities. Register here for the experience that suits you best!

We’re also bringing SAP TechEd on Tour to three additional cities:

  • Louisville
  • Sydney
  • Bangalore

Don’t miss your chance to be part of the global SAP community—virtually or on site—and immerse yourself in learning, collaboration, and inspiration.

entry.title: Re: How to Deploy/Publish RAP & Annotation based UI List...
entry.content:
Thanks, Sachin, I appreciate the update and the kind words

Since you’re blocked on the destination setup, here is a concise checklist that usually resolves BAS → S/4HANA Public Cloud deployment issues, with the correct SAP references.

Use the documented BAS → ABAP deployment path

In BAS, generate the Deployment Configuration (ABAP) and select your destination when prompted. SAP Help Portal-Generate Deployment Configuration ABAP

Overall flow (create app → deploy to ABAP from BAS) is here. SAP Help Portal-Develop an SAP Fiori Application UI and Deploy it to ABAP Using SAP Business Application Studio

Create the destination correctly (BTP Cockpit)

Protocol: HTTP; Host URL = your S/4HANA Cloud host; Authentication = Oauth2 SAML Bearer Assertion; Include sap-client.

Step by step, SAP’s guide shows you the exact fields and the SAML trust setup, including how to create a Communication System in S/4HANA Cloud for your BAS subaccount.

SAP-Connect SAP Business Application Studio and SAP S/4HANA Cloud System

Two common pitfalls that cause “authentication/destination configuration” errors

The email address of your BTP user must match the S/4HANA Public Cloud user (SAML bearer). Mismatches cause 'Service Unavailable' or authentication errors in Fiori tools. SAP Support Portal-3445942 - UI Development in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Frequently Asked Questions

Recheck the destination per SAP’s guidance if you see “verify destination configuration.”

How to perform a Quick tests

In BTP Cockpit → Destinations, run Check Connection and (if possible) open /sap/bc/adt to verify reachability.

Back in BAS, run Fiori: Deploy to ABAP and select the same destination.

If you prefer a full, click-through tutorial

End-to-end tutorial (create Fiori app in BAS and deploy to S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment). SAP-Create a SAP Fiori App and Deploy it to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment

Integration overview and related tasks: SAP Help Portal - Integrating the ABAP Environment with SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Once your Basis colleagues fix the destination, your current app should deploy smoothly via Fiori tools → Deploy to ABAP. If you encounter another specific error, paste the destination properties (mask secrets) and the exact error message, and I’ll identify help to fix it

All the best,
Chuma

entry.title: Supply Chain Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP 2508
entry.content:
The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release is here and delivers a broad range of innovations and enhancements across core business processes, focusing on greater automation, improved user experience, and deeper integration to help organizations run more efficiently in a cloud-first environment. Don't miss the highlights blog by Bert Schulze to find out more about the top innovations across the cloud ERP, or find out about the top AI & next-gen ERP features in this post by Yannick Peterschmitt.

With the supply chain specialists and logistics maestros in mind - this blog post dials in on the latest supply chain management features being rolled out in and around the 2508 release. With this release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, supply chain management takes another step forward in agility, intelligence, and integration. This update introduces a range of enhancements designed to optimize end-to-end processes, improve real-time visibility, and support faster decision-making across logistics and operations. Whether you're focused on inventory, transport, production, or delivery, the 2508 release brings innovative features that align with today's demand for resilient and sustainable supply chains. Check out the release video below for the quick summary of selected features, or read on below for more detail and some comprehensive E2E demos!

 

Core Logistics Topics

We'll kick things off with the latest core logistics features release in 2508, designed to enhance your fundamental supply chain execution and planning processes.


Inventory Management
Support for Copied Movement Types in SAP Fiori Apps for Goods movement

Flexibility to adapt business processes is a vital aspect of a dynamic supply chain, and custom movement types in SAP S/4HANA Cloud offer just that. These custom adaptations of standard movement types serve to bridge gaps where predefined scenarios may not meet particular business needs, allowing tailor-made solutions for unique business requirements. The SAP FIORI apps which support custom movement types have been extended to include Manage stock (F1062), Transfer Stock – In Plant (F1061) and Transfer Stock – Cross Plan (F1957).

One prominent use case for custom movement types arises when there’s a need to post goods movements to different General Ledger (GL) account determinations. While standard movement types seamlessly integrate with key SAP FIORI apps for goods movement, setting up a custom movement type involves a simple two-step process: first, copy an existing standard movement type in your configuration environment, assigning it a new character key starting with 9, x, y, or z, while adding any additional necessary details. The next step is to implement the custom Business Add-In (BAdI) MMIM_GR4XY_PROVIDE_DATA. This facilitates the availability of this newly created movement type alongside standard options in the supported FIORI apps, allowing users the flexibility to select the movement type that best fits their operational needs. This approach not only maximizes the system’s adaptability but also ensures streamlined and efficient management of specialized business processes.

For a step-by-step description of the implementing this process, check out this blog post.


(fig: Custom movement types displayed in Transfer Stock – In Plant)

New FIORI App - Manage Physical Inventory Document Items

In Inventory Management, a key theme of the 2508 release is the strategic modernization of the user experience to boost performance and analytical capabilities. With the 2508 release, we introduce the new app “Manage Physical Inventory document Items” (F8634) as a successor to transaction MI20 “Process physical inventory count results”, which has been deprecated. The experience switch is enabled on both apps, enabling users with the correct authorizations to switch between them with ease. The new app provides a clearer overview of physical inventory tasks, directly in the list view saving users time. The new app’s functionality doesn’t stop there; it empowers you to fine-tune your workflow through customization options. For instance, adding fields such as storage bin information can streamline precise material location management. Moreover, with enhanced filtering capabilities, you can now delve deeper into your data, allowing for a more nuanced analysis of inventory differences. With these improvements, transitioning to the Manage Physical Inventory Item List (F8634) app not only future-proofs your inventory operations but also enriches the way you interact with your inventory data.

Support for Barcode Scanning for Additional Goods Issues (Project / Asset)

A further new feature in inventory management – the "Manage Stock" app has been enhanced with barcode scanning for goods movements for both project stock and assets. New movement types for this stock have been introduced to streamline and optimize your inventory management processes. Efficiency gains come with the capability to leverage composite barcode scanning within the app. Users can select the new stock change options for goods issue projects or assets in the manage stock app, then assign the related WBS element or asset or sub-asset number respectively. This enhancement translates to faster and more efficient processing of inventory adjustments, reducing not just the margin for error but also the time spent managing inventory tasks. Overall, these updates are set to greatly enhance stock management workflows, making them not only more efficient but also more aligned with contemporary business needs.

Cross-Plant Transfer Posting with Item Lines

Item lists are a collection of material items that you can process together in warehouse or inventory processes. Whilst this is a familiar feature, with 2508 we have expanded where item lists are deployed to enhance inventory processes and introduce them to the “Transfer Stock – Cross Plan” application. Here, it is now possible to create a list of multiple items for stock transfer, enabling users to post items in one step and on one material document. This provides greater visibility as you see all transferred items in one list across plants and improves efficiency when checking movement history for several materials on one list.

Extensibility Updates

Enhancing process flexibility, this release introduces new extensibility options for material reservation applications. Businesses can now add custom fields to the user interfaces and underlying business logic for creating, changing, and displaying reservations. This allows companies to capture and process specific information relevant to their unique operational needs directly within the reservation document. For example, a business could add a field to track a project code or a specific reason for the reservation, improving data richness, enhancing reporting, and ensuring that custom process requirements are met without complex workarounds.

Handling Unit Management

Key to managing packaging, tracking and handling goods throughout your supply chain, we also have some updates to Handling Unit Management functionality. With this release, we introduce two key enhancements to Handling Units APIs.

Assign Serial Numbers to Existing Handling Units

A key innovation in this release is the enhancement of the Handling Unit (HU) OData API, which now supports the assignment of serial numbers to already created handling units—a critical capability that was previously missing. This enhancement addresses a functional gap left by previous API operations that only supported packing and posting goods receipt for production orders. Now, before a goods receipt is posted, serial numbers can be assigned to HUs via the API, streamlining processes where HUs are prepared in advance. This capability ensures better alignment with manufacturing and warehouse workflows where serialization is required before physical goods receipt.

The updated API enables serial number assignment through two supported scenarios: either by generating serial numbers automatically at production order creation (based on the serial number profile), or by receiving them from an external system via API communication. The API intelligently checks whether a production order already includes serial numbers and defaults to these when assigning to HUs, ensuring data consistency. This innovation not only supports developer extensibility and integration flexibility but also significantly enhances traceability and compliance in serialized environments—especially in regulated industries.

Enhanced Security for Production Supply Area Data

To strengthen integration security, the Production Supply Area (PSA) OData API now supports OAuth 2.0 authentication, aligning with modern SAP security protocols and standards. This enhancement ensures a more secure, token-based authorization process, enabling third-party applications to access SAP S/4HANA Cloud resources without exposing sensitive credentials in the payload. OAuth 2.0 improves trust and compliance for integrations, especially in multi-system landscapes where security and granular access control are critical.

This update also improves connectivity with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), making it easier to securely link external applications to SAP S/4HANA Cloud for PSA-related data access. Applications can now request specific scopes of access to user data, supporting role-based security and limiting unnecessary data exposure. With this change, customers gain more controlled, secure, and scalable integration patterns for managing production supply data across platforms.


Delivery Management

RAP events are standardized notifications that signal changes in business objects, enabling flexible and loosely coupled extensions in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. With the latest innovation, RAP events are now available for outbound delivery, inbound delivery, and customer returns delivery, empowering developers working with embedded extensibility (Developer Extensibility) to enhance their projects directly on-stack. You can implement custom logic to consume events such as Created, Changed, or Deleted for these delivery documents, as well as more granular events like Picking Status Changed or Item Created for outbound deliveries. This makes it possible to react instantly to delivery-related changes in your extensions built with the ABAP environment, while leveraging standardized events that increase development efficiency and consistency across solutions


Order Promising

Conversational Backorder Processing with Joule (Beta)

Imagine running a complex backorder processing (BOP) run by simply having a conversation. With the 2508 release, this is now a reality! Introduced initially as a BETA feature, from CFD release 2508.2, all users with a base license of Joule can leverage AI to automate BOP checks and processing.

Using simple, natural language commands in a chat, you can check stock situations and initiate a BOP run. For example, you can tell Joule you want to run BOP for a specific product and plant. In the background, Joule will prompt for which strategy you wish to implement with the default selection of “improve”, it creates the necessary BOP segment and variant, and processes the run—skipping multiple manual steps and app-toggling. This is a fantastic leap forward in simplifying a powerful process, and we are excited to hear how adopting this feature has enhanced your experience!

 

 

Display Product Availability Enhancements

With the 2508 release, we bid farewell to jumping between various transactions when seeking a comprehensive overview of product availability. The new Display Product Availability Fiori app is here to modernize and simplify your experience. Instead of scattered views, you now get all relevant availability information in a single, intuitive three-panel layout. At a glance, you see a high-level summary of available quantities, a detailed drill-down of MRP elements such as stocks and requirements, and a clear "Scope of Check" panel showing which supply and demand elements are included. With this release, the app now also includes the Analyze Product Availability feature. This allows you to dive deeper into product availability at the plant level. You can easily analyze product availability by selecting the plant you want to review and the app gives you a clear overview of confirmations, showing why certain quantities are available on specific dates and how concurrent demands impact stock or receipts. This makes it easier to respond to customer needs and share insights with stakeholders.

To dig deeper, you can drill down on MRP elements, adjust the date range to see planned changes, or view the scope of check to understand exactly which stocks, receipts, and requirements are considered. Horizon settings further explain why available quantities may appear positive, zero, or even negative. By surfacing these factors in one place, the app provides transparency and confidence in managing product availability.

See the new enhancements in the below demo video:

 

What’s more, with CFD release 2508.1, we extend these MRP features beyond the plant category to also account for storage locations. Conduct analysis and drill down on the same elements based on storage location with the same simplified UI panels within the Display Product Availability app.

Activating ATP Check for Subcontracting Outbound Delivery Creation

Many customers working with the subcontracting purchasing process face a key challenge: preventing outbound delivery notes from being created when there is no stock available. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud release 2508, we address this challenge by enabling ATP checks for subcontracting outbound delivery creation. Until now, the ATP (Available-to-Promise) check was not triggered for subcontracting deliveries, meaning delivery notes could still be generated even if stock levels are zero.

This gap can create inefficiencies, as users may be instructed to pick items that simply aren’t available in the warehouse. For companies which outsource parts of their manufacturing through subcontractors, accurate stock management is essential to keep production flowing. It is critical that only available and ready-to-pick stock is passed into subcontracting deliveries. Without validation, discrepancies between SAP and the actual warehouse stock can lead to delays, wasted effort, and disruptions in the supply chain.

By enabling configuration of the ATP check flag in the 2508 release, ATP  check can be enforced for subcontracting deliveries, ensuring that stock availability is validated before outbound deliveries are created. The result is clear: consistent order promising across the supply chain, improved accuracy, and smoother end-to-end operations.

 

Transportation Management

Stock transfer with delivery (BME) with warehouse management and transportation management(outbound)

One of the key challenges for supply chain specialists is managing outbound processes efficiently while ensuring seamless coordination between warehouse and transportation operations. Expanding on the outbound process defined in scope item “stock transfer with delivery (BME)”, with the 2502.3 release, we integrate both warehouse management and transportation management to streamline stock transfer orders end to end.

Customers can now create intra-company Stock Transport Orders (STOs) that automatically trigger Freight Unit (FU) creation in TM and generate Outbound Deliveries, which are processed through WM for picking, packing, and loading. A key new feature is dynamic delivery splitting—if not all handling units (HUs) can be loaded, the system automatically creates a new outbound delivery for the remaining goods. Additionally, TM now supports stock transfers from WM-managed locations, and includes batch-managed material data in freight documents. These updates provide customers with a fully integrated, automated logistics flow that improves supply chain visibility, operational efficiency, and flexibility—especially in dynamic warehouse and transport environments.

 

Enabling key user extensibility of freight document user interfaces

This feature introduces the flexibility to adapt the user interface of applications based on Web Dynpro ABAP (WDA)and Floorplan Manager (FPM), giving your business greater control over how classic application screens look and function. It addresses the common challenge of rigid UIs by empowering key users and technical teams to configure freight document interfaces—such as adding or removing fields, adjusting layouts, or rearranging elements—to match specific business needs. The feature allows you to adjust the structure of main UI pages, including the sequence and titles of tabs, as well as tailor the content of specific areas—for example, changing the order of fields, updating field labels, or hiding elements that aren’t relevant. With this update, we’re delivering clear value in supporting the customizing of UIs which better reflect your company’s specific use cases and processes, enabling users to interact with the applications more productively.

 

Warehouse Management

Keeping up with the Suite-First strategy, in 2508 much has been done to ensure that Warehouse Management functionality supports all scope items and process variations available within SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP. Take a look in more detail in this blog by Christian Ries. Below, we’ll focus on a few new features we want to highlight in particular.

Stock Removal Strategy for direct goods movement postings (EWM)

A much requested feature which we’re happy to roll out to customers, the Post Goods Movement app now includes a new button that triggers the stock removal strategy. This automatically determines the optimal storage bin, handling unit, and batch or serial number when posting a direct goods issue. Available for goods issue postings in manufacturing orders and reservations, this feature streamlines the process by aligning with your stock removal strategy to select the best storage bin. The result is greater efficiency and accuracy when posting goods issues, reducing manual effort and errors. Specifically designed for goods issue of production components, this enhancement ensures that the right stock is used at the right time—supporting faster, more reliable production execution.

Summarized JIT Calls 

This feature enables efficient handling of outbound deliveries that reference summarized Just-in-Time (JIT) calls within Warehouse Management. By integrating seamlessly with JIT processes, it ensures that deliveries comply with configured underdelivery and overdelivery tolerances. Leveraging the built-in warehouse management capabilities—such as picking, packing, staging, and loading—you can now handle outbound processing of summarized JIT calls (scope item 2EM) more effectively. Outbound deliveries with JIT references can be easily selected and processed within warehouse management, improving efficiency, accuracy, and reliability, while directly benefiting customers through more consistent and timely deliveries.

 

Integrating Extended Warehouse Management


Many of our customers have sophisticated supply chains and warehouse processes which involve central hubs and different satellite entities. With 2508, we are excited to roll out an integration scenario which will make managing such a set up much simpler. With the new communication scenario, Logistics - S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management Integration (SAP_COM_0A58), you can now integrate a decentralized Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) system in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition with your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This integration provides essential services to distribute and maintain inbound and outbound deliveries across hybrid landscapes. This helps your organization leverage existing EWM investments while expanding your cloud footprint, ensuring seamless data flow for critical delivery processes.

In-house Repair with Warehouse Management

A common challenge in after-sales service is managing the logistics of returning repaired products back to customers quickly and efficiently. With the 2508 release, we have enhanced the in-house repair process (scope item 3XK) by integrating warehouse management. This should streamline this process enabling companies to more efficiently define and execute their in-house repair workflows.

The process begins when a returned product is received and logged into the warehouse, where serial numbers are verified and the item is moved to a clarification zone for inspection. If an in-house repair is needed, a follow-up activity is created, ensuring the right material and serial number are tracked through the repair cycle. Once the product is fixed, an outbound delivery order is generated, and warehouse management takes over again to pick, pack, stage, and load the item for shipment back to the customer.



By leveraging warehouse management capabilities, organizations can optimize every step of the return—from picking and packing the repaired product to staging and loading it for shipment. This ensures accuracy, reduces manual effort, and speeds up turnaround times, ultimately improving the customer experience while driving efficiency in logistics operations. See the full process in the below End-to-End demo.


Summary

The 2508 release highlights in the supply chain management area of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition should help optimize your supply chain and logistics processes. If you have any questions, let us know via the comments below, or via the SAP Community. As new features are released in the CFD updates for 2508, I'll update this blog post - check at the top for the latest date where changes were made!

See you in release 2602!

entry.title: Re: WPDTC tcode calculation of PDT and deviation calculated?
entry.content:
To see exactly why it’s 2.0:

  1. Note the PO number and item from the WPDTC line.
  2. Go to ME23N → PO History tab for that item.
  3. Sum the GR quantities (movement type 101) that fall into your WPDTC selection period.
  4. Divide by the PO item quantity; you will likely get ~2.0.
  5. Check for reversals (102) and re‑postings; if they’re in your selection, they can inflate the total.

entry.title: Signavio Process Intelligence - SAP ABAP on Prem System Connection failed
entry.content:
Issue: SAP Signavio On-Premises Extractor -- Invalid SAP Connection

I have used this sap doc to configure this scenario - Connector - SAP ERP (RFC) | SAP Help Portal

Context

  • On-Premises Extractor installed and running on Linux with Java 17.

  • Extractor connects successfully to Signavio WebSocket (TLS/network OK).

  • SAP system reachable (dispatcher port open).

  • Connection in Signavio configured with valid SAP Dialog user (SAP_ALL + SAP_NEW, password logon allowed).

  • SAP GUI logon works fine with the same user, client, and password.

 

 

Problem

When testing the SAP RFC connection in Signavio, the extractor logs show:

 

 
Invalid credentials : NOT_FOUND ... cdata.jdbc.saperp.SAPERPDriver.connect(...)

This indicates that the extractor reaches SAP, but the SAP driver rejects the credentials.
I have already tried entering the username in UPPERCASE, but the error remains.

 

Cross-checks Performed

  1. Postman → CPI ✅ works

  2. Signavio → CPI (same endpoint as above) ❌ fails

  3. Signavio → SAP backend RFC (via On-Prem Extractor) ❌ fails

  4. SAP PO → SAP backend RFC ✅ works

The same SAP backend system and connection parameters work fine for SAP PO and other tools, but Signavio cannot connect when using the same endpoints.

Question

  • Has anyone else encountered the “Invalid credentials : NOT_FOUND” error when configuring an SAP RFC connection in Signavio?

  • Are there special requirements for how client, username, or password must be specified (e.g., restrictions on password characters)?

Looking for guidance on why the same back end SAP connection works fine in SAP PO and SAP GUI, but fails when tested from Signavio On-Premises Extractor.

entry.title: Re: ‌🎩‌The Magic of Attributes in SAP IAS: Default vs Enrich Assertion
entry.content:
Hi @dyaryura ,

Its a valid use case, however IAS mostly supports functions (lowercase , uppercase) and regex can mostly be used for filter.

From IAS documentation i can check that - Currently it is not supported, we can raise a feature request to IAS team to consider this scenario and use case. and below is the maximum which is supported by IAS:

<attribute_name> = <prefix> ${corporateIdP.<corporateIdP_attribute_name><:regex[filter]><:function[<method>]>} <suffix>

 Parameter Required Notes
attribute_nameYesThe name of the attribute as defined in the administration console. Free text.
prefixNoFree text.
corporateIdPYesFixed string, indicating that the value is taken from the assertion coming from the corporate IdP.
corporateIdP_attribute_nameYesThe specific attribute from the corporate IdP, whose value is taken.
:regex[<filter>]NoFilter the attributes from the corporate IdP.
:function[<method>]No

Methods to convert the attributes. Currently the supported methods are:

  • uppercase - the attribute is converted to uppercase letters.

  • lowercase - the attribute is converted to lowercase letters.

suffixNoFree text.

Now let's see some alternatives to implement this:

- In most of the scenarios - with these kind of requirements, we usually perform it in Identity provider or service provider, Like you said one way is to perform the operation at entra AD directly and use custom attribute to send it in assertion, or we can try at the service provider side where application accepts the whole UPN and then perform the string manipulation on its end.

- IPS can be used to sync that value from source to target - but i think it will be more efforts than just doing it on IDP or SP side.

entry.title: Re: Delivery date field update after PO confirmation posted
entry.content:
Unfortunately, there is no single IMG switch to say “don’t update EKET‑EIND when these fields change”.  SAP assumes that if you change a lead‑time‑relevant field, you want the schedule line dates recalculated.

That said, with some standard configuration options, there are a couple of standard levers you can check:

  • In SPRO → Materials Management → Purchasing → Purchase Order → Define Screen Layout at Document Level, you can make certain fields display‑only after PO confirmation, so they can’t be changed without cancelling the confirmation. This prevents the trigger altogether.
  • If you’re using PO confirmations (ZF/AB/ZB/ZG), the confirmation control key can be set up so that certain changes don’t trigger rescheduling — but this is limited and doesn’t cover all fields.
  • In some industries, you can use “statistical delivery date” fields for reporting instead of EKET‑EIND, so that operational changes don’t affect your analytics date.


The next option is if you want to suppress the date overwrite, and you want to allow the WROUTE/ship mode change. The cleanest enhancement points are BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST or User exit EXIT_SAPMM06E_013

entry.title: Re: Getting error while using this ODATA API to create bi...
entry.content:
Hello @anijaambika 

I have been analysing the error, and might have found why you received the error.
SDBIL_BD_RAP/012 is not supported because it's an SD document. The category is PBRQ, which means your reference is a Billing Document Request (BDR). BDRs (SD doc category PBRQ) are not valid input for the Billing Document API action POST /BillingDocument/SAP__self.CreateFromSDDocument. That action only accepts billable SD document categories, such as deliveries or order-related requests, like debit/credit memo requests. SAP Help Portal-Operations for Billing Document

Alternative options 2 supported paths.

If you must invoice the BDR
Use the standard BDR process to create the billing document: run Release Billing Requests (Fiori app) or the corresponding background job. There is a dedicated Billing Document Request API, but it is for read / reject/delete; creation of the billing document from a BDR is handled by the release/billing run, not by CreateFromSDDocument.

When integrating via the Billing Document API, create a billable SD document (e.g., a delivery or debit/credit memo request) and make a call to POST /BillingDocument/SAP__self.CreateFromSDDocument, referencing that document. This scenario is specifically supported by the API. SAP Help Portal-Operations for Billing Document

The flag AutomPostingToAcctgIsDisabled=true isn’t the root of your error; the real issue is the PBRQ category of the input document.

Helpful SAP Documentation

Billing Document Request – API & Apps (read/reject/delete via API, release via app/job). SAP Business Accelerator Hub-Business Accelerator Hub

Let me know how it goes

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Can we create an intercompany stock transfer order fo...
entry.content:
What you are describing is essentially a cross‑company‑code stock transfer of project stock, with the twist that the stock must remain assigned to the WBS element (project stock) after it moves from BE to NL, and that you want an intercompany billing at the end. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are two main intercompany process frameworks you can leverage — but there are also some important restrictions when it comes to valuated project stock.

For information, Project stock in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is valuated and tied to a WBS element. Cross‑company movements of project stock are not handled by the “classic” project stock transfer transactions (like MB1B) — they need to go through an intercompany stock transfer process so that both the logistics movement and the financial intercompany posting happen.

In Public Cloud, intercompany processes are delivered as scope items:

  1. 1P9 – Intercompany Stock Transfer (classic)
  2. 5HP – Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer (new framework with value chain monitoring)
  3. 1WO / 5D2 – Intercompany Sales (if you want to model it as a sale rather than a stock transfer)

To decide which process fits your case and since you want:

  • Stock to remain project‑assigned after the move
  • Physical movement from BE plant to NL plant (different company codes)
  • Intercompany invoice at the end

the closest fit in Public Cloud is Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer (scope item 5HP), but you need to check whether WBS‑assigned stock is supported in your release. As of recent releases, Advanced ICO supports valuated stock in transit and can carry account assignment (like WBS) through the transfer — but this is something to confirm in your tenant or with SAP, because in some earlier releases project stock was excluded from ICO scope.

entry.title: Dynamically setting chart positions based on measure values
entry.content:
The 4 KPIs (numeric point charts) are dynamically positioned left to right based on the measure value they contain.
  Highest on the left , lowest at the far right.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Setup overview
1. Script variable: 'charts'   type: chart    array: true

2. Onitialisation Script

// populate the dropdown with members of the sales manager dimension
var mem=Chart_1.getDataSource().getMembers("Sales_Manager__5w3m5d06b5");
Dropdown_1.addItem('All');
for (var i=0;i<mem.length;i++)
	{Dropdown_1.addItem(mem[i].id,mem[i].description);}
Dropdown_1.setSelectedKey('All');

//populate the charts script variable with all charts in the story
charts=Application.getWidgets({type:WidgetType.Chart});


3. Dropdown_1 onSelect Script

var key=this.getSelectedKey();
for(var i=0;i<charts.length;i++)	{charts[i].getDataSource().removeDimensionFilter("Sales_Manager__5w3m5d06b5");
	 if(key!=='All') {	 charts[i].getDataSource().setDimensionFilter("Sales_Manager__5w3m5d06b5",key);}}

Timer_1.start(1);

4. Timer_1  onTimeout Script

// re-order charts high to low - left to right

// Step 1: Set up two typed arrays
var chartNames = ArrayUtils.create(Type.Chart);  // chart.getName()
var chartValues = ArrayUtils.create(Type.number); // converted rawValue

// Step 2: Populate both arrays
for (var ia = 0; ia < charts.length; ia++) {
    var name = charts[ia];
    var raw = charts[ia].getDataSource().getResultSet()[0][Alias.MeasureDimension].rawValue;
    var value = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(raw);

    chartNames.push(name);
    chartValues.push(value);
}

// Step 3: Bubble sort both arrays together — high to low
for (var i = 0; i < chartValues.length - 1; i++) {
    for (var j = 0; j < chartValues.length - i - 1; j++) {
        if (chartValues[j] < chartValues[j + 1]) {
            // Swap values
            var tempVal = chartValues[j];
            chartValues[j] = chartValues[j + 1];
            chartValues[j + 1] = tempVal;

            // Swap corresponding chart names
            var tempName = chartNames[j];
            chartNames[j] = chartNames[j + 1];
            chartNames[j + 1] = tempName;
        }
    }
}

// Define starting position and spacing
var leftPos = 50;         // Starting X position
var spacingGap = 50;      // Gap between charts

// Reposition each chart based on the previous chart's width
for (var iz = 0; iz < chartNames.length; iz++) {
    var chart = chartNames[iz];

    // Set chart left position
    chart.getLayout().setLeft(leftPos);

    // Update leftPos for the next chart
    var chartWidth = chart.getLayout().getWidth().value; // Get current chart width
    leftPos = leftPos + chartWidth + spacingGap;
}

The Chart sorting is placed in a Timer as we need to ensure the data has fully refreshed before trying to retrieve the values and apply the chart sort.

Hello @karan3032l 

There is no such a function a reservation release. You can set "movement allowed" field in a reservation, so a material document can be posted against the reservation. That can be done either with MB22 or MBVR. However that won't change stock levels.

I guess you want to post a material document against the reservation. That can be done with MIGO.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: Signavio Process Intelligence - SAP ABAP on Prem Syst...
entry.content: @AkumaryafirAk The evidence conclusively points to a misconfiguration of the SAP Java Connector (JCo) used by the On-Premises Extractor, not your SAP user credentials or permissions. The error NOT_FOUND is a classic JCo indicator that it cannot find the specified destination or establish a proper connection context, which the CData driver then misleadingly reports as an "Invalid credentials" error.Your SAP user works in SAP GUI and PO because they use native SAP connectivity libraries. The Signavio Extractor uses a Java-based stack that relies on a correctly configured JCo layer, which is not being set up properly via the Signavio UI alone

entry.title: Re: how to release record that has been created from BAPI...
entry.content:
Please note, when you create a reservation with BAPI_RESERVATION_CREATE1, you are only creating the requirement record in table RESB/RKPF and it does not move stock. That is why you don’t see any change in unrestricted stock. If your goal is to “release” it so that the stock is actually moved from unrestricted to the reservation (or consumed from it), you need to follow up with the appropriate goods movement posting.

Further, in the context of "Release", there’s no separate “release” function for a reservation. The reservation affects available stock immediately (ATP check), but unrestricted stock quantity in MMBE only changes when you post a goods issue against the reservation. If you want to “free” the stock back to unrestricted, you either delete the reservation, or post a goods movement that reverses the reservation consumption.

So to post and clear the Reservation, with the standard transactions like MB1A or MIGO, where select Goods Issue → Reference Document = Reservation. Enter your reservation number, movement type and post. Alternatively, you can also post the stock via BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE

entry.title: Late Stay Hours vs. Varying Operating Times - SAP TM PUDL
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m looking for some guidance to see if anyone has dealt with this scenario before and found a good solution.

Our client has a rule that for sales orders raised with delivery priority 5, the requested delivery date can be extended by 5 days. This extension must respect the customer’s working hours and cannot deliver on weekends.

In the PUDL condition for delivery priority 5, I’ve maintained the operating hours check and added 50 hours of late stay. Since this customer operates 10-hour days, the system correctly calculates the extended requested delivery date.

The challenge is that our client has many customers with different operating hours. Using a standard 50-hour late stay results in inconsistent delivery dates depending on each customer’s operating hours.

Has anyone come across this issue and found a way to consistently apply a set-day rule while still accounting for different operating hours?

Thank you,
